question: can the brim on this hat be shaped so that the front and back slope downwards?
answers: hello ryan , the ontario rat ii with the black handle comes in two blade styles . a satin finish  ok8860 ) and the black finish  ok88601 ) . the geometry of the blade is less important on how it holds an edge than what kind of steel it is made of . they are both made of aus 8 steel . the aus series stainless steel contains vanadium , unlike the 440 series steel , which increases its wear resistance and edge retention . the vanadium allows a sharper edge to be put on the blade . the hardness of the steel in the rat ii is hrc 55-56. i believe the description on amazon is wrong . it says the hardness is 58-60. there is a tradeoff  inverse proportion ) between hardness and toughness . the harder a blade is , the more brittle  less tough ) it will be . a hard blade will hold an edge longer , but will be more susceptible to breaking . a blade with an rc hardness less than 52 is considered soft . a blade with an rc hardness greater than 60 is considered very hard  brittle ) . so the rat ii with a hardness of rc 56-58 is a good mix of toughness and edge retention . you can checkout my article on knife blade steel at www.glenscampingtips.com/ ? page_id=42 . the clip is pretty standard as far as folders with clips . i believe it sticks out about an eighth of an inch . thanks , glen from campingstuff
prediction: yes, it's a very nice hat and the front is very comfortable for me to wear in my daily life

question: does the noise really subside after using it several times?
answers: tritium is a radioactive isotope of hydrogen , and it does not glow in the dark . as it decays slowly into helium , it emits electrons  called beta decay ) . the inside of the tiny vial in the sight is coated with a phosphor . when the tritium electrons hit the phosphor , the phosphor emits the light ; this is called fluorescence . some extra info : there are many phosphors , but none of them contain phosphorus . they contain various elements such as zinc , copper , sulfur , etc . different combinations emit different colored light . the tritium has a half-life of about 13 years . therefore , after 13 years , only half of the tritium in the gun sight will remain . this does not necessarily mean that the sight will be only appear half as bright to your eyes in total darkness ; it is possible that it will seem nearly as bright as when you bought it . i can better answer this in 13 years . sorry for the long answer .

question: is the slide metal?
answers: per the manufacturer , mcnett , thank you for contacting us . typically when coating a fabric in polyurethane , manufacturer 's will coat the underside or inside of the fabric . the polyurethane makes the fabric `` waterproof . '' manufacturer 's will also typically apply a water repellent  like revivex nubuck , suede & fabric waterproofing spray ) on the opposite side of the fabric on the outside . this water repellent causes water to bead up and roll off the fabric . it is the fabric 's first line of defense . in case water does begin to penetrate into the fabric , the polyurethane coating will prevent it from soaking through completely . it is the fabric 's second line of defense . that said , you will not typically apply the water repellent to the polyurethane coated side . instead , it is usually applied to the outer fabric to help water bead up and roll off the fabric . the funny thing about polyurethane is that manufacturer 's use it to waterproof fabrics , but one of the quickest ways to break down a polyurethane coating is by saturating it in liquid . this is the reason the coating is typically applied to the underside or inside of the fabric and it is also the reason why manufacturer 's recommend that you do n't store polyurethane treated fabrics  i.e. , backpacks , tents , etc . ) wet or damp . the moisture may cause it to break down . that said , i would not recommend spraying anything directly onto the polyurethane coating . again , water repellents like revivex nubuck , suede & fabric waterproofing spray should be applied to the opposite side of the fabric on the outside . i would recommend covering any metal parts , simply because i 'm not sure how they were treated or manufactured and because of that , i do not know how they will react to any type of liquids . covering it with a piece of scotch tape should suffice .
prediction: it's not a metal but it does have some good grips on the side of the barrel

'' use a die that is in close agreement with your chamber and your brass will last an infinite number of reloadings . use a factory spec die unless you really have a special need for `` small-base '' sizing like using machine-gun fired brass .
